Description

We are all Homo sapiens (Stringer, Chris, ). By exploring our search for the earliest common ancestor with Homo neanderthalensis (Stringer, Chris, ), we can deepen our understanding of our species' family tree. While this may seem like a simplification, it clearly demonstrates our shared humanity.

Animal evolution unfolds over vast stretches of time, punctuated by occasional bursts of rapid change (Sperling, Erik A., et Richard G. Stockey, , pp. 605-622). In contrast, the evolution of language progresses swiftly (Fitch, W.T., , 3-33). This rapid linguistic evolution enables us to categorize and label groups of people and events, inadvertently fostering the perception of differences among us.

Some previously published families have been temporarily hidden until the standardization process is complete. Although they are not currently visible here, they remain available in the GitHub repository (History Tracers, Github).
The events can be updated or added at any time based on new research.
